conclusion: Analyze the path of the light ray through the prism to determine its direction when it exits.

The prism is a right triangular prism with a cross-section ABCD. The light enters the prism at point O on the line AD. Given: angle OAB = 60 degrees, AB = BC = 8 cm, OA = 2 cm, and refractive index n = sqrt(2).
The light enters perpendicularly at point O along AD, so it travels straight through to point A without bending.
At point A, the light ray will refract as it enters the prism.
Use Snell's Law: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2). Here, n1 = 1 (air), n2 = sqrt(2) (prism), and theta1 = 60 degrees.
Calculate sin(theta2): sin(60 degrees) = sqrt(3)/2, 1 * sqrt(3)/2 = sqrt(2) * sin(theta2), sin(theta2) = sqrt(3)/(2sqrt(2)) = sqrt(6)/4.
The light travels from A towards B inside the prism.
At point B, the light will exit the prism.
The angle of incidence at B is the same as the angle of refraction at A, which is theta2.
Use Snell's Law again: n2 sin(theta2) = n1 sin(theta3). Here, n2 = sqrt(2), n1 = 1, and theta2 = arcsin(sqrt(6)/4).
Calculate sin(theta3): sqrt(2) * sin(theta2) = 1 * sin(theta3), sin(theta3) = sqrt(2) * sqrt(6)/4 = sqrt(12)/4 = 2sqrt(3)/4 = sqrt(3)/2.
The light exits the prism at point B at an angle of 60 degrees with respect to the normal to the surface BC.
The light ray exits the prism at point B at an angle of 60 degrees with respect to the normal to the surface BC, traveling in the direction away from the prism.
